title: Project Tiger
sub-heading: Revised Guidelines for the Ongoing Centrally Sponsored Scheme

title: National Tiger Conservation Authority
content:
Ministry of Environment & Forests 
Government of India

title: Introduction to Project Tiger
content:
Project Tiger is an ongoing Centrally Sponsored Scheme of the Ministry of Environment and Forests. The revised guidelines incorporate the additional activities for implementing the urgent recommendations of the Tiger Task Force, constituted by the National Board for Wildlife.

These include support for implementing the provisions of the Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006. The activities are as below:

(i) Antipoaching initiatives
(ii) Strengthening infrastructure within tiger reserves
(iii) Habitat improvement and water development
(iv) Addressing man-animal conflicts
(v) Co-existence agenda in buffer / fringe areas with landscape approach
(vi) Deciding inviolate spaces and relocation of villages from crucial tiger habitats
(vii) Rehabilitation of traditional hunting tribes living in and around tiger reserves
(viii) Providing support to States for research and field equipments
(ix) Supporting States for staff development and capacity building
(x) Mainstreaming wildlife concerns in tiger bearing forests outside tiger reserves
(xi) Providing safeguards / retrofitting measures in and around tiger reserves
(xii) Strengthening the infrastructure of National Tiger Conservation Authority
(xiii) Carrying out independent monitoring and the evaluation of tiger reserves.
(xiv) Establishment and development of eight new tiger reserves.
(xv) Provision of project allowance to all categories of staff working in tiger reserves.
(xvi) Providing residential amenities to facilitate basic education
(xvii) Providing assistance to States for fostering ecotourism

title: Objectives of Project Tiger
content:
“Project Tiger” was launched in April, 1973 with the objective “to ensure maintenance of a viable population of Tigers in India for scientific, economic, aesthetic, cultural and ecological values, and to preserve for all times, areas of biological importance as a national heritage for the benefit, education and enjoyment of the people”.

Currently there are 28 Tiger Reserves in 17 states, covering an area of 37761 sq. km. Apart from above ‘in principle’ approval for creation of eight new Tiger Reserves has been accorded. The selection of reserves was guided by the need to conserve unique ecosystem/habitat types across the geographic distribution of tigers in the country.

Project Tiger is an ongoing Centrally Sponsored Scheme, which is continued, in the XIth five-year Plan. Conservation of endangered species and their habitat, strengthening and enhancing the Protected Area Network, control of poaching, monitoring, research and ensuring people’s participation in Wildlife Conservation have been accorded high priority in the National Wildlife Action Plan and the Wildlife Conservation strategy, 2002.

title: Funding and Activities Supported
content:
During present plan period, 100% Central Assistance is being made available to States for expenditure on all non-recurring items; for recurring items, the Central Assistance is restricted to 50% of the expenditure, while the matching grant is provided by the Project States.

The activities / field inputs under Project Tiger, interalia, include : (Non recurring) strengthening of protection, deployment of armed squads in tiger reserves, creating basic infrastructure for management, roads, wireless, civil works, habitat development, augmenting water resources, compensatory ameliorative measures for habitat restoration, eco-development, village relocation, use of Information Technology in crime detection, establishment of a digitized database in Tiger Reserves having collaborative linkage with Project Tiger Directorate in the GIS domain, monitoring and evaluation of tiger reserves, monitoring of habitat status, carrying out All India Estimation of Tigers, Co-predators and Prey animals in the GIS domain with the state of art technology, continuous monitoring of tiger populations in various tiger range states (tiger reserves and other forest areas outside tiger reserves), fostering wildlife viewing for tourists in Tiger Reserves, providing compensation to villagers for human deaths/livestock depredation by carnivores in tiger reserves, staff welfare measures, providing 'Project Allowance' to all categories of staff working in Tiger Reserves, establishment of veterinary facility, and fostering research / research projects relating to tiger conservation, replacement and purchase of new vehicles for existing and new Tiger Reserves to ensure staff mobility.
(Recurring) creation / deployment of local work force for patrolling/barriers, habitat improvement, providing salt licks, water facility, fire protection measures, maintenance of various items, publicity and extension and legal assistance.

title: Need for a Statutory Authority
content:
Project Tiger highlighted the need for a statutory authority with legal backing to ensure tiger conservation.
Recommendations from the National Board for Wild Life led to a Task Force.
Key recommendations included:

*   Strengthening Project Tiger with statutory and administrative powers.
*   Creating the Wildlife Crime Control Bureau.
*   Submitting an annual report to Parliament.
*   Addressing concerns of local people.

title: Urgent Recommendations of the Task Force
content:
*Reinvigorating governance.
*Strengthening protection efforts, checking poaching, convicting criminals, and breaking international trade networks.
*Expanding undisturbed areas for tigers by reducing human pressure.
*Repairing relationships with local people through coexistence strategies.
*Regenerating forest habitats by investing in forest, water, and grassland economies.

title: Ecological Disturbances in Tiger Reserves
content:
Tiger Reserves face ecological disturbances, including:

*   Fragmentation of habitats due to overuse.
*   Conflicting land uses leading to habitat loss.
*   Significant village populations with large cattle numbers causing degradation.
*   Disturbances from temples and commercial entities (e.g., tea estates).
*   Man-animal conflicts, resulting in mortality.

title: Constraints Affecting Field Implementation
content:
Several constraints affect field implementation:

*   Delayed release of Central Assistance.
*   Staff vacancies and aging field staff.
*   Lack of capacity building initiatives.
*   Weak enforcement and monitoring.
*   Need for greater commitment and vigilance from States.
*   Required capacity building and supervision in field administration.

title: Strengthening the System
content:
Urgent need to strengthen the system at the Central Government level (Project Tiger Directorate).
Involvement of Parliament is required for review and guidance.
Involvement of Chief Ministers of States is important.
Strengthening field administration and supervision is crucial.
Building a participatory base by including local people's interests is extremely important.

title: NTCA: A Statutory Authority
content:
Project Tiger has been converted into a statutory authority (NTCA).
Enabling provisions in the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972 through an amendment (2006).
Addresses ecological and administrative concerns for tiger conservation.
Provides a statutory basis for protection of tiger reserves.
Strengthens institutional mechanisms for protection of ecologically sensitive areas and endangered species.

title: NTCA's Role
content:
The NTCA will ensure:

*   Enforcing guidelines for tiger conservation and monitoring compliance.
*   Placement of motivated and trained officers as Field Directors.
*   Facilitating capacity building of officers and staff.
*   Implementing a time-bound staff development plan.

title: Tiger: Still Endangered
content:
Despite decades of Project Tiger, the tiger remains endangered.
Causative factors include:

*   Loss of habitat due to agriculture and development.
*   Revenge killings due to man-animal conflicts.
*   Demand for body parts in the illegal international market.
Continuance of a focused, species-specific project like ‘Project Tiger’ is crucial to address these threats.

title: Key Imperatives in Tiger Conservation
content:
Three key imperatives in tiger conservation:

*   A focused approach to prioritize actions within and outside tiger reserves.
*   Eliciting the support of local stakeholder communities.
*   Ensuring the necessary infrastructure for protection and management.

Conservation of tiger has ecological national significance transcending State boundaries.

title: Tiger Distribution and Density
content:
Tigers are present in the forests of seventeen states.
Distribution and density vary due to:

*   Forest cover and terrain.
*   Natural prey availability.
*   Undisturbed habitat.
*   Quality of managerial efforts.
Tigers are indicators of the well being of the ecosystem. A healthy population shows that other ecological components are equally robust.

title: Ongoing Activities and Support
sub_heading: Revised Centrally Sponsored Scheme of Project Tiger focuses on anti-poaching efforts and strengthening protection measures to ensure tiger conservation and reduce human-animal conflict. These initiatives are vital for sustainable tiger populations.

title: Anti-Poaching Activities (Ongoing)
content:
Anti-poaching operations are site-specific, including:

*   Deployment of anti-poaching squads.
*   Establishing and maintaining patrolling camps and deploying laborers.
*   Organizing vehicular patrolling (Tiger Protection Force).
*   Establishing and maintaining wireless network.
*   Organizing surprise raids with local police.
*   Ensuring special protection measures during monsoon ('Operation Monsoon').
*   Deployment of ex-army personnel/home guards.
*   Deployment of local workforce for patrolling.
*   Procurement of arms and ammunition.
*   Procurement/maintenance of elephant squads.
*   Rewards to informers.

title: Project Tiger: Strengthening Conservation Efforts
sub-heading: Enhancing Tiger Reserves and Addressing Human-Wildlife Conflict

title: 4.1 Legal Support & Procurement
content:
Legal support for defending court cases.
Procurement of vehicles, boats.
Procurement field gear, night vision device.

title: 4.2 Infrastructure Strengthening in Tiger Reserves
content:
Reinforcing the infrastructure of Tiger Reserves includes:

Civil Works: staff quarters, family hostels, office improvement, patrolling camp, house keeping buildings, museum, culverts.
Maintenance/creation/upgradation of road network.
Maintenance/creation of wireless tower.
Maintenance/creation of fire watch tower.
Maintenance/creation of bridges, dams, anicuts.
Maintenance/creation of firelines / firebreaks.
Maintenance/creation of earthen ponds.
Procurement / maintenance of vehicles (Gypsy, Jeep, Truck, Tractor).
Habitat improvement works.
Procurement of hardware, software / GIS.
Procurement of compass, range finder, GPS, camera traps.
Procurement of satellite imageries for management planning.
Map digitization facility for management planning.

title: 4.3 Habitat Improvement & Water Development
content:
These may include: weed eradication, removal of gregarious plant growth from grasslands, grass improvement, water retention structures and the like.
These initiatives would increase the forage and browse values of the habitat for wild animals.

title: 4.4 Addressing Human-Animal Conflict
content:
This would involve:

Payment of compensation for cattle lifting, death of human beings and crop depredation* due to wild animals.
Creation of crop protection structures.
Procurement / deployment of traps, cages to catch problematic animals.
Procurement of tranquilizing equipments, rescue vehicles and drugs.

*crop depredation would be supported as per prevailing norms of the State, in the delineated buffer area as explained in Section 38V of the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, as amended in 2006.

title: 4.5 Co-existence Agenda in Buffer/Fringe Areas
content:
Fringe areas around Tiger Reserves have corridor value. Ecological sustainability is important to prevent the area from becoming ecological sinks on account of over use of resources and unwise land use.

This calls for delineation of buffer zone around a tiger reserve to incorporate such fringe areas so that it can fulfill the following objectives:

Providing ecologically viable livelihood options to local stakeholders for reducing their dependency on forests.
Conserving the forest area through restorative inputs involving local people for providing habitat supplement to wild animals moving out of core areas.

A comparative assessment of the forest cover status of outer fringe areas of tiger reserves upto a radial distance of 10 kms. has been done in collaboration with the Forest Survey of India. The States are required to delineate the fringe/buffer area around the core zones of tiger reserves, and submit a Tiger Conservation Plan as required under Section 38 V of the Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006, to ensure wildlife conservation while addressing the livelihood issues relating to local people.

title: 4.6 Rehabilitation for Hunting Tribes
content:
There is an urgent need to launch a rehabilitation and development programme for the denotified tribes and tribes involved in traditional hunting, living around tiger reserves and tiger corridors. The following denotified tribes / communities are involved in traditional hunting of wild animals : Behelias, Ambalgars, Badaks, Mongias, Bavariyas, Monglias, Pardhi, Boyas, Kaikads, Karwal Nat, Nirshikaris, Picharis, Valayaras, Yenadis, Chakma, Mizo, Bru, Solung and Nyishi.

The rehabilitation / welfare package should be evolved in a site specific, consultative manner with livelihood options, to include : wages for such people towards their deployment in foot patrolling for protecting wildlife, providing agricultural land with irrigation, basic health care, housing and related community welfare inputs and basic education facilities.

title: 4.7 Research and Field Equipments
content:
The All India tiger estimation using the new methodology approved by the Tiger task Force has resulted in a permanent monitoring protocol for the field units.

Assistance would be provided for fostering field oriented research and to equip the staff with facilities like GPS, camera traps, night vision, range finder and related accessories including hardware and software.

The tiger reserves are required to carry out the day to day monitoring of wild animals using the refined process in the GIS domain, which would enable “forecasting” vis-à-vis wildlife protection.

title: 4.8 Staff Development & Capacity Building
content:
This would involve:

Capacity building / training.
Providing project allowance and special incentives.
Specialized training in the use of GIS, antipoaching operations.
Specialized training in jurisprudence and wildlife forensics.
Study tours for appraisal of good practices in other reserves.
Dissemination workshops.
Specialized training in park interpretation.
Specialized training in management planning.

The above inputs are extremely important for enhancing the skill of field staff. Several instances of poaching occur for want of specialized training in crime detection and related skills.

title: 4.9 Inviolate Spaces & Relocation
content: The Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, as well as the Scheduled Tribes and Other Traditional Forest Dwellers (Recognition of Forest Rights) Act, 2006, require that rights of people (Scheduled Tribes and other traditional forest dwellers) recognized in forest areas within core/critical tiger/wildlife habitats of tiger reserves/protected areas may be modified and resettled for providing inviolate spaces to tiger/wild animals.

title: Village Relocation and Tiger Conservation
sub-heading: Addressing Human-Wildlife Interaction in Core Areas

title: Statutory Requirements and Compensation
content:
Relocation requires compensation for rights settlement.
Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, Section 24 allows acquisition of land rights for Sanctuaries or National Parks.
Sub-section 2 authorizes the Collector to acquire land/rights.
Compensation for immovable property is a statutory requirement for settling rights.

title: Ecological Imperative of Inviolate Core Areas
content:
Tiger ecology research indicates a need for inviolate space of 800-1000 sq km to maintain a viable tiger population (80-100).
Tigers are an umbrella species, ensuring viable populations of other wild animals and forest.
Maintaining the core areas of tiger reserves is ecologically vital for tiger and other wildlife survival.

title: Proposed Relocation Package
sub_heading:
Options and Norms for Village Relocation/Rehabilitation,
Considering National Rehabilitation and Resettlement Policy, 2007.
Addressing difficulties relocating people living in forest areas.

title: Relocation Package Options
content:
Option I: Payment of entire package amount (Rs. 10 lakhs per family).
No relocation/rehabilitation process by the Forest Department.

Option II: Relocation/rehabilitation of village from protected area/tiger reserve by the Forest Department.

title: Monitoring and Implementation
content:
(i) Option I: Monitoring by District Magistrate to ensure proper rehabilitation.
Handholding mechanism by external agencies.
Deposit portion of amount in a nationalized bank for interest income.

(ii) Option II: Package (Rs. 10 lakhs per family) breakdown:

rows: Agriculture land procurement (2 hectare) and development
Community facilities commuted by the family

title: Relocation Process Monitoring
content:
The relocation process would be monitored / implemented by two Committees:

State level Monitoring Committee:
(a) Chief Secretary of the State - Chairman
(b) Secretaries of related departments - Members
(c) State Principal Chief Conservator of Forests - Member
(d) Non-official members of respective Tiger Conservation Foundation - Members
(e) Chief Wildlife Warden - Member-Secretary

title: District Level Implementation Committee
content:
District level Implementing Committee for ensuring convergence of other sectors:
(a) District Collector - Chairman
(b) CEO - Member
(c) Representative officials from: - Members
PWD, Social Welfare, Tribal Department, Health Department, Agriculture Department, Education Department, Power and Irrigation Departments
(d) Deputy Director of the Tiger Reserve/PA - Member Secretary

title: Flexibility and Priorities
content:
Cost norms are indicative, allowing flexibility for State/site-specific situations.
Inter-component and inter-family adjustments are permitted by State Governments.
Relocated villages receive priority for eco-development and local development.
Labor-oriented works are preferably implemented through relocated villagers.

title: Post-Relocation Support
content:
Resettlements on forest land will have access to forest resources through village level committees and Gram Sabhas.
District Administration facilitates fair price shops, education, and health centers.
Handholding after relocation through the forest department and district administration.
Relocated villagers are given priority for livelihood options.

title: Cost Considerations and Open-Ended Process
content:
State Government must cover extra cost if relocation exceeds Rs. 10 lakhs per family.
Relocation is an open-ended process, progress depends on State performance.

title: Mainstreaming Wildlife Concerns
sub_heading:
Fostering corridor conservation through restorative strategy.
Involving locals to arrest fragmentation of habitats. (New activity) (non-recurring)

title: Corridor Conservation
content:
Forests connecting Tiger Reserves or Protected Areas have tigers and other wild animals.
No Scheme for addressing wildlife concerns in such areas currently exists.
Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2006, provides for addressing such corridor areas.
This involves:
- Redressing man-animal conflict.
- Capturing problematic / aberrant wild animals.
- Monitoring of wild animals.
- Antipoaching operations.
- Habitat improvement measures.

title: Addressing Man-Animal Conflict
content:
Communities near National Parks, Sanctuaries, and Tiger Reserves suffer crop damage from wild herbivores.
Situation acute due to reliance on a single annual rain-fed crop with low productivity.
This is a major cause of man-animal conflicts.

title: Tiger Conservation
sub-heading: Strategies and Activities for Wildlife Protection

title: Addressing Human-Wildlife Conflict
content:
Reserves and Protected Areas are crucial, but local support is essential for wildlife conservation.

Section 11 of the Wild Life (Protection) Act allows for the killing of wild animals causing damage, but this is often unpopular due to religious sentiments.

Trapping and translocation are often not feasible or cost-effective.

Compensating communities around Tiger Reserves for recurring losses is vital, following state norms and Section 38V of the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972 (amended 2006).

title: Safeguarding Wildlife: Retrofitting Measures
content:
Tiger Reserves are impacted by infrastructure like roads and railways.

High-tension electric lines pose electrocution risks.

Site-specific safeguards and retrofitting measures are necessary to protect wild animals.

title: Strengthening Project Tiger Infrastructure
content:
Focusing on Project Tiger Headquarter expenditure for consultancy, all India tiger estimation/continuous monitoring of tigers outside tiger reserves, strengthening of NTCA at the Center and establishing a monitoring lab in the Wildlife Institute of India.

Creation of office space at Delhi for National Tiger Conservation Authority.
Creation of GIS outstation laboratory at Wildlife Institute of India.
Carrying out All India Tiger Estimation, monitoring.
Support to research work.
Contractual arrangement for special studies.
International / National Workshops.
Contractual arrangement for data entry, analysis.

title: Independent Monitoring and Evaluation
content:
Independent monitoring of tiger reserves is crucial.
The process uses 45 parameters evaluated by experts based on the IUCN format.
Monitoring reports undergo peer review by the IUCN.
This process would be continued during the XIth Plan period after further refinement.

title: Expanding Tiger Reserves
sub_heading:
Establishment and development of eight new Tiger Reserves to enhance conservation efforts.
Aiming for a holistic ecosystem approach to maintain stability and viable tiger populations.
Addressing community pressures and habitat fragility for effective conservation.

title: Ecosystem Approach
content:
‘Project Tiger’ employs a holistic ecosystem approach.

Focus is on the ‘tiger’, while maintaining ecosystem stability at other trophic levels.

This ensures a ecologically viable population of tiger, at the apex of the food chain.
Tiger habitat has become fragile in developing countries, India included, warranting a focused conservation approach.
Tiger Reserves are analogous to 'islands', needing species preservation owing to ecological insularization.

title: Addressing Habitat Degradation
content:
Fragmentation of tiger habitats is aggravated by:

Degraded forest cover due to biotic pressure.
Dislocated prey – predator ratio.
Absence of effective protection measures.
Lack of eco-development initiatives for fringe communities.

'Project Tiger' aims to redress these issues.

title: New Tiger Reserve Expansion
content:
The Steering Committee of Project Tiger recommended inclusion of new Tiger Reserve areas.
The total area of Project Tiger from existing 37761 sq. kms. to 50,000 sq. kms. during the X Plan period.

Proposals for new Tiger Reserves were received from some States, on which ‘in principle’ approval has been accorded.

rows: Udanti and Sita Nadi Wildlife Sanctuaries
Dandeli Wildlife Sanctuary and Anshi National Park
Sanjay National Park and Sanjay Dubri Wildlife Sanctuary

title: Financial Implications
content:
A total of 8 new Tiger Reserves are proposed to be included in Project Tiger.
An additional financial implication of Rs. 32.00 crores during the plan period.

title: Project Allowance for Staff
content:
Providing project allowance to Ministerial staff is a new component.
The officers / staff of Tiger Reserves receive Project Allowance as approved by the EFC/CCEA during IX plan period.
The offices of Tiger Reserves are located in remote places, making ministerial support critical.
Extending the project allowance to ministerial staff working in Tiger Reserves is proposed to attract talent.

title: Staff Welfare Activities
content:
Field staff serve in remote, difficult areas, facing endemic diseases and risk of encounters with wildlife.
Postings are often ‘non-family postings’, increasing the financial burden on staff.
Field staff face pressures from local communities due to restrictions on forest resource access.
Physical assaults on staff are common.
Providing amenities for staff welfare is essential to attract talent.

title: Staff Welfare & Eco-Tourism in Tiger Reserves
content:
Supporting staff welfare includes residential accommodation for children of frontline staff, supply of kerosene, medicine, field kit, mosquito nets, and torches.

Ecotourism is ecologically sustainable nature-tourism, distinct from mass tourism. It emphasizes sustainable, equitable, community-based efforts to improve living standards of local communities.

Financial support to the host community is provided through soft loans from Ecodevelopment Committees, based on site-specific Ecotourism plans and the carrying capacity of Tiger Reserves in buffer areas.

The core/critical tiger habitats would not be used for tourism. Ongoing tourism activities in such areas should be phased out.

Development of tourism related facilities within buffer zones will continue with Project Tiger inputs. Stakeholder opportunities include management of low cost accommodation, guide services, sale outlets, excursions, and ethnic dances.

title: Memorandum of Understanding (MoU)
content:
Tiger Reserve States are required to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding with the Ministry of Environment and Forests.

Tiger Reserves receive funding support under the Centrally sponsored Scheme of Project Tiger based on a reserve-specific Tiger Conservation Plan.

This plan adheres to Section 38-V of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972, as amended in 2006, and follows guidelines issued by the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA).

The centrality of Panchayati Raj Institutions should be ensured through consultation for deploying local workforce, addressing man-animal conflicts, providing livelihood options, managing village relocation, and fostering eco-tourism.

title: Annexure-I: MoU Details
sub_heading:
Between National Tiger Conservation Authority and Government of [State Name].
Agreement for financial assistance for the protection and development of [Tiger Reserve Name].
NTCA extends financial support for approved items of work outlined in Article-II.

title: Article I: State Government Agreements
content:
The State Government agrees and affirms:

(a) Delineation of the buffer zone around core/critical tiger habitats and preparation of a Tiger Reserve specific Tiger Conservation Plan.

(b) Filling staff vacancies for effective implementation and field protection.

(c) Ensuring funds released by NTCA are used for Annual Plan of Operations works immediately, with compliance to guidelines.

(d) Estimated costs are based on actual approved rates of PWD of the concerned State.

(e) Empowering the Director/Officer Incharge to spend money as per NTCA and State Government norms.

(f) The proposal references the Tiger Conservation Plan, forming the basis of the APO.

title: Article I: Continued
content:
(g) APO must indicate the location/area of proposed initiatives on a map, along with physical target, financial target, and unit rate with basis of estimation.

(h) Progress report should indicate physical achievement (quantity, number, area indicating location) and objectives fulfilled.

(i) A year-wise photo catalogue of physical targets shall be maintained for verification.

(j) During execution, details of estimate, man-days involved etc. shall be displayed near the work site.

(k) Utilisation Certificate showing unspent balance shall be furnished annually by 31st May. Complete Utilisation Certificate upon work completion.

(l) Accounts of grants shall be maintained properly and open to NTCA/Audit inspection. In construction/habitat improvement works, photocopies of measurement books shall be sent to NTCA.

title: Article I: Continued (Financial)
content:
(m) The State Government will ensure accounts are audited annually by Statutory Audit and a certificate sent to NTCA by 31st May.

(n) Funds will be used only for the sanctioned purpose. Diversion requires prior NTCA approval.

(o) Records of all assets acquired out of the grant shall be available for scrutiny. Assets cannot be disposed of or utilized for other purposes without approval.

(p) A statement showing extracts of assets created shall be furnished to NTCA annually by 31st May.

title: Article II: NTCA Financial Assistance
content: NTCA agrees to provide financial assistance as 'NTCA share' as grant for execution of work items. (Specific items and amounts would be detailed here)

title: National Tiger Conservation Authority
sub-heading: Financial Assistance and Work Execution Agreement

title: Article III: Delays and Withdrawal of Assistance
content:
In case of delays in work execution, the State Govt. must notify the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) in writing, providing reasons for the delay.

If the NTCA determines that work is not progressing according to the agreed work plan, it reserves the right to withhold or withdraw financial assistance.

Upon communication of the decision to withdraw financial assistance, any unspent grant amount must be immediately returned to the NTCA.
